summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment. The defense argues the indictment was obtained in violation of the Sixth Amendment because the grand jury was drawn from the White Plains Division during the COVID-19 pandemic, which allegedly systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division where the alleged crimes occurred.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of involvement in Jeffrey Epstein's crimes. Her attorneys are filing this motion to dismiss the indictment against her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the individual whose New York residence was the alleged location of unlawful sexual activity. His indictment anniversary is mentioned as a potential motive for the timing of Maxwell's indictment.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed the memorandum.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who certified service of the document.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim.

persons.name: Jeffrey Martin
persons.context: An expert who analyzed the racial and ethnic composition of jury wheels for Manhattan and White Plains. His declaration was submitted in a similar case (U.S. v. Balde).

persons.name: Judge Faillzt
persons.context: Presiding judge in the U.S. v. Balde case, which is referenced as having a similar challenge to the use of a White Plains grand jury.

connections.description: Maxwell is alleged to have intended for a minor victim to engage in unlawful sexual activity with Epstein at his New York residence, as per the referenced indictment.
Mark S. Cohen is listed as an attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, authoring and submitting this legal memorandum on her behalf.
Christian R. Everdell is listed as an attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell and certified service of this document.
Jeffrey S. Pagliuca is listed as an attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell.
Laura A. Menninger is listed as an attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell.
Bobbi C. Stemheim is listed as an attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell.
Jeffrey Martin submitted an expert declaration in the case U.S. v. Balde, which is before Judge Faillzt.

events.title: Sealed Indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government filed a sealed indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell in the Manhattan Division of the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Announcement and Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government publicly announced the indictment and arrested Ghislaine Maxwell. The defense alleges this date was chosen to mark the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein's indictment.

events.title: Manhattan Grand Jury Seated
events.description: According to a referenced email from a court official, a Manhattan grand jury was seated, four days before Maxwell's indictment.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Dismiss Memorandum
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys filed this memorandum in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment.

locations: Manhattan Division (New York, Bronx, Westchester, Putnam, Rockland counties)
White Plains Division (Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange, Sullivan, Dutchess counties)
keyFacts: The defense argues Ghislaine Maxwell's indictment was obtained using a grand jury drawn from the White Plains Division, which systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division where the alleged crimes occurred.

An expert analysis by Jeffrey Martin found the White Plains qualified jury wheel was 8.76% Black and 10.48% Hispanic, compared to the Manhattan Division's eligible juror population of 20.92% Black and 28.06% Hispanic.

The defense claims the government chose the White Plains grand jury to meet a 'publicity-driven' deadline of July 2, 2020, the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein's indictment, despite a Manhattan grand jury being available by June 25, 2020.
The memorandum cites the case U.S. v. Balde as having a similar legal challenge regarding the use of a White Plains grand jury for a Manhattan case during the COVID-19 pandemic.
